<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.

<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarTimedWait_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarTimedWait_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_time_t *abs_wakeup_time)
{
    struct timespec                    limit;
    int                                status;
    OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);

    limit.tv_sec  = OS_TimeGetTotalSeconds(*abs_wakeup_time);
    limit.tv_nsec = OS_TimeGetNanosecondsPart(*abs_wakeup_time);

    pthread_cleanup_push(OS_Posix_CondVarReleaseMutex, &impl->mut);
    status = pthread_cond_timedwait(&impl->cv, &impl->mut, &limit);
    pthread_cleanup_pop(false);

    if (status == ETIMEDOUT)
    {
        return OS_ERROR_TIMEOUT;
    }
    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```

explanation: No calls to any of the <string.h> functions listed in MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.) are present in the provided function. The operations in the function are: numeric extraction into a struct timespec (limit.tv_sec, limit.tv_nsec), a table lookup via OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, and POSIX pthread calls (pthread_cleanup_push, pthread_cond_timedwait, pthread_cleanup_pop). None of these are string.h functions or wrappers of the listed string functions, so there is no direct risk of accesses beyond object bounds from string handling in this fragment. Note: the OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro or the implementations of OS_TimeGetTotalSeconds / OS_TimeGetNanosecondsPart could internally use string functions — if you suspect those implementations, they should be inspected separately. However, within the code shown here there are no string.h usages to investigate under Rule 21.17.
